articles.headline: No Coincidence Here: Trump’s Bezos Attack Was a Valentine to The Enquirer
articles.snippet: It wasn’t a new thing, for the president to go after the Amazon founder. But it was odd to see him making nice with his onetime friend David J. Pecker.
articles.abstract: It wasn’t a new thing, for the president to go after the Amazon founder. But it was odd to see him making nice with his onetime friend David J. Pecker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even by the tweeting habits of the 45th president of the United States, it was a puzzler.

articles.headline: U.S. Steel Companies Face Downturn Despite Trump Claims of Revival
articles.snippet: American steel manufacturers got an initial boost from Mr. Trump’s tariffs but have since seen their share prices decline and steel prices fall.
articles.abstract: American steel manufacturers got an initial boost from Mr. Trump’s tariffs but have since seen their share prices decline and steel prices fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has latched on to the idea of using steel to build his wall along the southern border, praising himself for fulfilling two campaign promises at once: keeping out illegal immigrants and resuscitating a struggling industry.

articles.headline: Jayme Closs, Kidnapped by a Stranger, Endured Horror, Police Say
articles.snippet: Investigators say the suspect, Jake Patterson, mapped out a plot to abduct the middle-school student after a chance sighting at a school bus stop.
articles.abstract: Investigators say the suspect, Jake Patterson, mapped out a plot to abduct the middle-school student after a chance sighting at a school bus stop.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARRON, Wis. — The crime began with a chance encounter: From the moment Jake Patterson spotted a 13-year-old girl boarding a school bus last fall, he “knew that was the girl he was going to take,” Wisconsin investigators said in court documents released on Monday.
articles.byline: By Matt Furber and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Republicans Are in Lock Step With Trump on Shutdown. But for How Long?
articles.snippet: In Trump country, even some furloughed federal workers are backing the president’s wall demands, and keeping Republican senators in line as the shutdown stretches on.
articles.abstract: In Trump country, even some furloughed federal workers are backing the president’s wall demands, and keeping Republican senators in line as the shutdown stretches on.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARKERSBURG, W.Va. — On Day 20 of the partial government shutdown last week, a small band of federal workers, shivering in 25-degree weather, staged a rally to send what their organizer, Eric Engle, said was a message to Senator Shelley Moore Capito: “We need to end this shutdown. If it takes overriding the president, that’s what it takes.”

articles.headline: Steve King Removed From Committee Assignments Over White Supremacy Remark
articles.snippet: Republicans voted Monday night to remove Mr. King from the House Judiciary and Agriculture committees after he made remarks questioning why white supremacy is considered offensive.
articles.abstract: Republicans voted Monday night to remove Mr. King from the House Judiciary and Agriculture committees after he made remarks questioning why white supremacy is considered offensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders removed Representative Steve King of Iowa from the Judiciary and Agriculture Committees on Monday night as party officials scrambled to appear tough on racism and contain damage from comments Mr. King made to The New York Times questioning why white supremacy is considered offensive.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel, Jonathan Martin and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: At Trump’s Inauguration, $10,000 for Makeup and Lots of Room Service
articles.snippet: New details of spending on President Trump’s inaugural two years ago show that it roughly doubled that of his immediate predecessors.
articles.abstract: New details of spending on President Trump’s inaugural two years ago show that it roughly doubled that of his immediate predecessors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Private donors put up $107 million to usher Donald J. Trump into office in style two years ago, and it is now clear just how enthusiastically his inaugural committee went to town with it.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Sharon LaFraniere and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Huawei’s Reclusive Founder Rejects Spying and Praises Trump
articles.snippet: Ren Zhengfei, C.E.O. of the Chinese tech giant, said he would wait to see if President Trump intervened in the case of his daughter, who is accused of fraud.
articles.abstract: Ren Zhengfei, C.E.O. of the Chinese tech giant, said he would wait to see if President Trump intervened in the case of his daughter, who is accused of fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — To entrepreneurs in China, he is a legend akin to Steve Jobs.

articles.headline: Goodbye, New York. Adam Moss Is Leaving the Magazine He Has Edited for 15 Years.
articles.snippet: At 61, an editor known for his obsessive style steps away from a publication that told New Yorkers where to eat and what to think. “I don’t wake up obsessed every morning, and I used to,” he said.
articles.abstract: At 61, an editor known for his obsessive style steps away from a publication that told New Yorkers where to eat and what to think. “I don’t wake up obsessed every morning, and I used to,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Moss, whose visual savvy and ear for the zeitgeist made him one of the leading magazine editors of his generation, said on Tuesday that he would step down from New York magazine, his canvas for the past 15 years.

articles.headline: Court Blocks Trump Administration From Asking About Citizenship in Census
articles.snippet: Critics had accused the Trump administration of trying to turn the census into a tool to advance Republican political fortunes.
articles.abstract: Critics had accused the Trump administration of trying to turn the census into a tool to advance Republican political fortunes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge blocked the Commerce Department from adding a question on American citizenship to the 2020 census, handing a legal victory on Tuesday to critics who accused the Trump administration of trying to turn the census into a tool to advance Republican political fortunes.
